DataElement.preferredName: Radiation Therapy Breast Carcinoma Medical Device Tissue-Equivalent Biomedical Material Thickness Administered Measurement
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the thickness of the bolus (a biomedical material applied to the surface of the skin to increase the radiation dose at the skin surface) used during radiation therapy for breast carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Radiation Therapy Breast Carcinoma Medical Device Tissue-Equivalent Biomedical Material Thickness Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the administration of breast carcinoma (a carcinoma arising from the breast) radiation therapy and the thickness (the dimension between two surfaces of an object) of a tissue-equivalent (a substance equal to in effect or significance to an anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix) biomedical material (any substance other than pharmacologic substance used in biomedical research or in constructing devices or prostheses) applied to the surface of the skin to increase the radiation dose at the skin surface of a patient.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: use PHOTOTHERAPY, LASER THERAPY, or ULTRAVIOLET THERAPY for therapeutic radiation with visible, laser, or ultraviolet light, respectively.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Property.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Medical Device Tissue Equivalent Biomaterials Thickness Administered
Property.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.:Any physical object that is useful for prevention, diagnosis, monitoring, or treatment of disease or other conditions.:An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.:A person or thing equal to another in value or measure or force or effect or significance etc; being essentially equal to something.:synthetic or industrial materials intended for use in contact with human tissues.:The dimension between two surfaces of an object, usually the smallest dimension as opposed to the width or the length: also, viscous consistency.:The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
Any physical object that is useful for prevention, diagnosis, monitoring, or treatment of disease or other conditions.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
A person or thing equal to another in value or measure or force or effect or significance etc.; being essentially equal to something.
Any substance other than pharmacologic substance that can be applied in biomedical research or in constructing artificial organs, devices, or prostheses that can be introduced into the human body.
The dimension between two surfaces of an object, usually the smallest dimension as opposed to the width or the length: also, viscous consistency.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the thickness of the bolus (a biomedical material applied to the surface of the skin to increase the radiation dose at the skin surface) used during radiation therapy for breast carcinoma.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
